text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, that is why. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Aximun scan may help and may also confuse thing. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But I'll hear from you anything that says we got to rush to therapy make a decision right now that I just need to figure out. We are adding Aximun scans to our scanning facility but we don't do them now. Patient: Right.

text: Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me. Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. We would never put you at risk for safety. If let's say you're just sick with something, it's not cancer related. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You don't come down. You got to do this hard thing. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing.

text: Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Well that’s why I want to go that route you know. Doctor: Yeah and you did the right thing. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Because if you had uh advanced disease it’s better to take it out first and then give radiation therapy as opposed to getting radiation therapy and then doing surgery. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The surgery is much more difficult, the side effects are more prevalent - Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - in patients who’ve had radiation therapy followed by surgery.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer. Family Member: Mm, hmn. Doctor: But that would be potentially something you could participate in. Right now I would be a little bit worried about putting you on it with these gasping things that I can’t explain- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because it might affect our ability to get the therapy in. Uhm, we have another study which I, uh - Transformer - we have a first-in-human study of a drug that comes from plum seeds. In laboratory studies it looks like it can attack and kill prostate cancer cells. So this is a study where we’re looking at a drug that now is in I.V. form to see how often does it affect the PSA, how often do you get side effects that we can’t give it to you. So it’s more about the side effects and whether it helps you or not. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Some of the data says that it could help you, but we don’t know. We’ve never given it to enough men. We treat a number of men and if they do okay, then we go to a higher dose.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be…

text: Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. Not like it’s spinning, but you just don’t have a sense of where you are, and then you right yourself, but, obviously, we don’t want you to fall. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
